questions.question: A patient presented with a painless swelling and watering in his left eye. Examinationrevealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding hisdiagnosis?

options.A: It needs to be surgically treated.
options.C: It does not have malignant potential.
options.D: It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation.DAILYROUNDS389

questions.explanation: A painless swelling on the lower lid is suggestive of a chalazion (tarsal cyst/meibomian cyst). It hasthe malignant potential to become an adenocarcinoma of the meibomian gland.Chalazion is the chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation (option D) of the meibomian gland(option B). It presents as painless swelling of the eyelid. It is more common in adults thanchildren. Treatment includes incision and curettage (option B) and intralesional injection oftriamcinolone acetate.396

questions.question: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude thepossibility of
questions.explanation: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude thepossibility of sebaceous gland carcinoma.Note: A chalazion can undergo malignant change into sebaceous gland carcinoma(adenocarcinoma of meibomian gland).Recurrences of chalazia are not uncommon. However, the physician should entertain thepossibility of malignancy in such cases and should biopsy a lesion that recurs or appears atypical.The pathologist should be alerted to the suspicion of sebaceous gland carcinoma and frozensections and lipid stains should be requested.

questions.question: A patient presented to the clinic with severe left eye pain, watering, and swelling of the lid for2 days. He says it's difficult to see the laptop screen while working and he is unable tocomplete his daily targets. On examination, tender swelling is noted as shown below. What isthe cause of this finding?
questions.explanation: The patient has acute presentation and painful swelling in the palpebral conjunctiva as shown inthe image, suggestive of internal hordeolum. It is an acute suppurative inflammation of themeibomian gland associated with blockage of the duct.Other options:Options A and B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the acute staphylococcal infection of the hairfollicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland.DAILYROUNDSOption D: Chalazion is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of theMeibomian gland.397DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: What is the length of the nasolacrimal duct?DAILYROUNDS390
questions.explanation: The nasolacrimal duct is 12-18 mm long.The lacrimal drainage system consists of the lacrimal sac, which is 10-12 mm long. It lies in thelacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and thefrontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and isdirected downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus ispartially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner).The puncta are openings on the lid margin. There are two canaliculi from the puncta. Eachcanaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: Vertical (2 mm) and horizontal (8 mm). Thesuperior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens intothe lateral wall of the lacrimal sac. A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs thejunction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into thecanaliculi.The image below shows structures of the lacrimal apparatus.398LacrimalglandExcretoryducts of thelacrimal glandLacrimal-sacNasolacrimalductLacrimal ApparatusUppercanaliculusOMARROWCommoncanaliculus- LowercanaliculusValve ofHasner

questions.question: Where does the nasolacrimal duct open?
questions.explanation: The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus.The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and isdirected downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus ispartially covered by a mucosal fold, called the valve of Hasner. The valve of Hasner preventsreflux from the nose.

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman came for an eye exam due to a gritty sensation that has been causingher a lot of discomfort. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosedwith keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film.In keratoconjunctivitis sicca, patients present with irritation and foreign body sensation. Marginaltear strip is reduced. The conjunctiva become dry and lustreless with positive Rose Bengalstaining. Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca:•Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)•Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca•Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)• Lacrimal gland deficiencies - congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal• Lacrimal gland duct obstruction - old trachoma, burns, SJS• Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes) - Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensoryblock399

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the phenol red test for dry eye?

options.B: It measures tear production based on the length of colour change in the thread
options.C: If color changes to blue, it depicts mucin deficiency.

questions.explanation: Phenol red test measures the tear production according to the length of colour change in thethread.In phenol red test, the alkalinity of tears changes its colour to bright orange on contact. It doesn'trequire anaesthesia (unlike Schirmer's test). Three millimetres of a fine dye-impregnated 75-mmcotton thread is placed under the lateral one-fifth of the inferior palpebral lid margin for 15seconds.Based on length of colour change,•>20 mm - normal tear production• 10 to 19 mm - borderline dry eye•<10 mm severe dry eye

questions.question: 391Identify the test shown below.
questions.explanation: The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which isused to check for dry eye.Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film.Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eyeincludes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) orsurgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).Other tests for dry eye include:• Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink andappearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilledin the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp.• Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye.• Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer.Other options:Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colourblindness.Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye.Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a doubleprism mounted on a slit-lamp.

questions.question: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for dry eye disorder. As apart of your study, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Whichthe following patients would not be included in your study?among

options.A: A 26 year old patient showing decreased levels of lactoferrin in tear samples
options.B: A 20 year old patient showing tear film break up at 18-20 seconds
options.C: A 24 year old patient showing A pattern stain in Rose bengal staining
options.D: A 22 year old patient showing Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm

questions.explanation: A patient with tear film break up at 18-20 seconds is considered to be normal. All the otherpatients have dry eye.400Tear film break-up (BUT) time is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of afirst randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucincomponent of tears.Inference:• 15-35 seconds - normal• < 10 seconds- unstable tear filmOther options:Option A: Tear samples can be assayed for the presence of markers known to be decreased (e.g.lactoferrin) or elevated (e.g. matrix metalloproteinase-9) in dry eye. This is known as tearconstituent measurement.Option C: A patient with A pattern on Rose Bengal staining has severe dry eye.Option D: A patient with 9mm wet Schirmer strip has moderate dry eye.

questions.question: The findings of a test done in a patient under evaluation for dry eye are shown below. Identifythe test.392
questions.explanation: The image above depicts lacrimal scintigraphy.Lacrimal scintigraphy (dacryoscintigraphy) is used to assess the lacrimal drainage function. Aradioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac. Its path is thenvisualised with an Anger gamma camera. It is useful for the evaulation of watering eye.Other tests for evaluation of watering eye include regurgitation test, syringing, fluorescein dyedisappearance test (FDDT), Jones dye test and dacryocystography.Other options:Option A: In regurgitation test, steady pressure with the index finger is applied above the medialpalpebral ligament.Option B: In dacryocystography, a radioopaque material is inserted into the lacrimal sac,following which X-rays are taken.Option C: The image shows the Jones dye test.401Jones dye test2 drops of fluorescein dye on conjunctiva-Cotton bud placed in inferior meatus dipped in 136 xylocaineMAfter 5 minCheck staining in cotton budPositivoPrimaryhypersecretionNegativePartial obstructionorLacrimal pump failureJones-1 testNegative Jones-1 tostPlace another cotton bud in inferior meatusMAPositiveLacrimal syringingCheck stainingPartialobstructionNegativepump failureJones-II testMARROW

questions.question: What is the site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis?
questions.explanation: The site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis is the nasolacrimal duct.Congenital dacryocystitis occurs due to the stasis of secretions in the lacrimal sac due tocongenital blockage in the nasolacrimal duct. Membranous occlusion at its lower end near thevalve of Hasner is the commonest cause.The image below shows a neonate with congenital dacryocystitis.

questions.question: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month-old child. There is a history ofwatering and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best nextstep in the treatment?393
questions.explanation: DAILYROUNDS402The image showing right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye issuggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massagewith topical antibiotics.Congenital dacryocystitis is chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborn infants. It occursdue to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. More than 90% of patients with undergospontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.Treatment of congenital dacryocystitis depends on the age of the child:• Less than 9 months: Massaging (Crigler's massage which increases the hydrostatic pressurewithin the sac) and antibiotic eye drops•• 9 months to 4 years: ProbingOlder children (> 4 years): Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) gives the best result. InDCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with watering from the right eye for 1 year. Syringing revealed apatent drainage system. Rest of the ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosisof lacrimal pump failure was made. Which of the following test will help in the confirmationof the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Lacrimal pump failure can be confirmed with dacryoscintigraphy.Lacrimal pump failure means an inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctumfor drainage. It is also called functional obstruction and may be secondary to lower lid laxity ororbicularis muscle weakness (eg. facial nerve palsy. It is confirmed by dacryoscintigraphy, inwhich a radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac and its pathvisualised with an Anger gamma camera. An atonic lacrimal sac is seen.Note: In cases of partial obstruction of the lacrimal apparatus, forced injection of fluid into thecanalicular system (dacryocystography) can overcome the obstruction sites and point to adiagnosis of lacrimal pump failure. Thus, dacryoscintigraphy is better for the confirmation oflacrimal pump failure.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis.Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.explanation: The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)DCR involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sacwith the lateral nasal mucosa. It re-establishes the lacrimal drainage and is hence the preferredsurgery for chronic darcyocystectomy.Chronic dacryocystitis is a long-standing inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Streptococcushemolyticus and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common etiological agents. Initial treatmentis with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents. Sequelae include lacrimal fistula formation andmucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis.Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy. Treatment of lacrimal fistula isdacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).403

questions.question: A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduledfor dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the
questions.explanation: After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus.Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimalsac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directlyfrom the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.

questions.question: What is the most common ocular manifestation in mumps?
questions.explanation: The most common ocular manifestation in mumps is dacryocystadenitis.Dacryocystadenitis, or inflammation of the lacrimal gland, is seen in mumps. It presents as apainful swelling in the lateral part of the upper lid.

questions.question: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.explanation: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is also the most commonepithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.Pleomorphic adenoma, or benign mixed tumor, presents commonly in middle age as a slowlyprogressive painless swelling in the upper outer quadrant of the eyelid. The bone is usually notinvaded in these tumors. They are treated by surgical removal along with their intactpseudo-capsule.Malignant tumors of the lacrimal gland such as adenoid cystic carcinoma (option A),mucoepidermoid carcinoma (option C) and malignant mixed tumor (option D) generally occur inthe elderly with a short history of appearance, rapid progression and pain. These tumors alsopresent in the upper eyelid and are known to invade the adjacent bones. Radical surgicalprocedures and high dose radiotherapy are necessary for the removal of the tumor. Adenoid cysticcarcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.Both malignant and benign tumors are known to push the eyeball downwards and inwards whilerestricting the upwards and outwards movement of the eyeball.The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:•Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)• Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)• Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)•Mucoepidermoid carcinoma404
